ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PHYSICAL EDUCATION AND SPORTS IN SCHOOLS
(Adequacy of guidelines and safety measures)


    1. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the Minister for Education, in view of recent incidents, whether the guidelines and safety measures adopted for physical education and sports in schools are adequate.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The Ministry of Education shares the same concern with Dr Ong Chit Chung, Member for Bukit Batok, on accidents involving our school children during physical education and sports activities.

    However, the Ministry of Education would like to reassure parents that guidelines and safety measures adopted for physical education and sports in schools are adequate. These are reflected in great detail in various documents such as (1) The Principals' Handbook, (2) The Handbook on School Sports, (3) Prevention and the First Aid Treatment of Medical Problems in Sports, and (4) Safety in School.

    Seminars are conducted for sports secretaries and other key school personnel by the Singapore Sports Council and the Training and Health Education Department of the Ministry of Health to explain the importance of safety in sports as outlined in these handbooks.

    Schools have also been given a list of names by the School Health Service Department of the Institute of Health of students with medical problems who should refrain from participation in competitive games, physical fitness test and physical education lessons.

    The Ministry of Education constantly reminds schools of the need for safety in all physical education and sports activities through regular meetings and workshops. The Ministry also disseminates, on a regular basis, useful articles related to safety in physical education and sports.

Column: 596

In recent years, physical education and sports equipment and facilities have also been upgraded with safety of students as a main consideration. The provision of synthetic rubberised running tracks and the use of sponge balls and plastic bats are examples.

    We will continue to monitor and review our guidelines and safety measures as and when necessary.

     Dr Ong Chit Chung (Bukit Batok): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether the Ministry keeps track of such incidents systematically so as to monitor the trend and take any remedial action, when necessary, and whether the teachers would routinely or systematically ask students if they have any specific medical problem or they are feeling unwell on a particular day. I would also like to ask whether the Ministry is training teachers or has trained teachers to provide emergency aid or measures when necessary.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry keeps track of all incidents and accidents that may happen in school from time to time and reviews these occasions and makes recommendations for improvement on safety. As for pupils who are not well on certain days when there are physical education exercises, they do report to the school authorities and to the physical education teachers and if they have medical certificates to show that they cannot take part in certain vigorous activities they are exempted from these activities.

    Finally, it is part of the physical education training programme for physical education teachers that safety in sports and games is in the curriculum so that when they become teachers in schools they are familiar with the precautions that have to be observed.

SOLICITORS' SCALE FEES FOR CONVEYANCING
(Retention)


    2. Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked the Minister for Law what are the reasons for retaining the solicitors' scale fees for legal work relating to conveyancing.

Column: 597



     The Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the reason for retaining the solicitors' scale of fees for conveyancing is to protect the public who are clients of lawyers in property transactions. With the system of scale fees, the client can be sure that the fee is not arbitrary and is determined on the basis of a common criterion. It also prevents over-charging and avoids disputes between solicitors and clients in relation to conveyancing work.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, may I ask the Minister for a review of the current system of standard pricing for conveyancing matters. In this review, Sir, may I also ask the Minister to consider allowing para-legal persons, other than solicitors, to handle conveyancing matters, particularly with regard to titles registered with the Registry of Land Titles and Deeds which, I understand, constitute the majority of real estate titles in Singapore, and the competition will make sure that there will be no over-charging.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, on his first point concerning the review, I will be happy to refer this to those who are now charged under the Legal Profession Act with administering the scale. Under the Legal Profession Act, the decision on the scale fees is entrusted to a statutory committee comprising the Chief Justice, the Attorney-General, the President of the Law Society, and two solicitors nominated by the Law Society. I will be happy to refer this matter to them and also to discuss with the Law Society the arguments for a review.

    As to his other point of allowing non-lawyers to do certain kinds of conveyancing, I am aware that in certain countries they have allowed banks and other agencies to engage in such work. Whether this can be done in Singapore or not, I think, needs careful consideration. The primary consideration must be the interest of the public who will be the clients and who will be the potential vendors or purchasers. We must also bear in mind that conveyancing is a highly specialised and indeed technical area of the law. But I would not like to preclude or pre-empt the decision to be taken on this. It has been

Column: 598

done in other countries, perhaps it can be done here. But I would like to discuss this with the members of the legal profession and I assure the Member that I will take this up.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, there are large transactions of resale of HDB flats. I wonder if the Minister is willing to look into the scale fees in relation to the resale of HDB flats. At the moment, I believe the lawyers in the HDB are charging a rate which is very much below the present scale fees for private properties. I wonder whether the Minister can look into this area and have a set of scale fees which is perhaps lower than the scale fees relating to private property but slightly above that of the HDB rate because there are many ---

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, are you making a speech? Can you ask your question?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: --- lessees of HDB flats who would like to engage their own private solicitors. But the scale fees at the moment are quite prohibitive.

     Prof. Jayakumar: The thrust of Mr Heng Chiang Meng's question is diametrically opposite to what Mr Chiam is saying. I am not conversant at this stage with the details of the HDB transactions but I am under the impression that HDB transactions are in fact not governed by the scale fees under the solicitors' scale and that this benefits a large number of Singaporeans who purchase HDB flats. But since he has raised this point, this can also be a matter which I will refer to the committee for consideration.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, can I ask the Minister whether his reply to Mr Heng to undertake a study regarding the possibility of introducing the non-legal profession into the scheme of conveyancing constitutes a commitment to this House to initiate that particular study.

     Prof. Jayakumar: It must follow that when I said that I will review, it will be reviewed.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, may I ask the Minister just to reiterate this point. He said that the scale fees are to protect the interest, and that includes the financial

Column: 599

interest, of the public, and not to protect the earning capacity of lawyers.

     Prof. Jayakumar: It depends on who is looking at it from which way. It can of course be said to also protect the interest of the lawyers in the sense that certain fees are fixed. But in the ultimate analysis, from my point of view, in these matters, it is the interest of the public that is paramount.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR

1ST APRIL, 1991 TO 31ST MARCH, 1992

Head M (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [14th March, 1991],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head M of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." [Mr Goh Chee Wee].

    Question again proposed.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, I wish to raise the issue on the privatisation of hawker centres.

    It has now been more than two years since the Government decided that hawker centres be sold or leased to private groups to run on a commercial basis. My question to the Minister is simply this. Is the Government going ahead with its plans?

    Sir, there is concern from stallholders that this is going to cause some amount of hardship. After all, most of the stallholders have got there because of hardship problem and if in the beginning we were prepared to help them, it would appear that now, some years later, we are withdrawing our service to them. I think more important is to consider assisting existing stallholders to upgrade the older hawker centres which are not doing well, ensure the quality of food is good, it is nutritional and generally help the business of the centre. When all this is in place, then we can go ahead with the privatisation.

Column: 600



    If we go ahead with the programme, the high cost will naturally affect many stallholders. This programme can be implemented in new centres when everybody starts from square one and also in those that are doing extremely well like the Newton Hawker Centre, for example, where stallholders are definitely making quite a bit of money. For them to pay market rates and not enjoy the high subsidy will be no problem at all. But we certainly cannot say the same with some, say, in Telok Blangah and in some other parts of the country.

    We must also accept the fact that many of the stallholders are our senior citizens. We cannot expect them to relocate easily or find alternative employment. Even if we allow them to stay in the newly privatised centres, I do not believe they can cope with the introduction of high-tech methods that these centres would have. Sir, I believe that upgrading the facilities should be the first step, and a better way for the stallholders and for the community at large.
12.45 pm

    I also wish to state that complaints that customers are shortchanged with poor quality food and badly prepared food is a fact, but it is a separate issue. Yes, I agree that people should not be subjected to this at all, but the answer is not to immediately privatise and leave the stallholders high and dry. We must solve that problem too. Give him a chance to improve, upgrade the facilities and then he will have no choice but to upgrade the quality of his food.

    I urge the Ministry to carefully study the matter and give due consideration to the plight of stallholders before going ahead with its plan to privatise. That hawker centres will one day be modern and managed in a commercial way is inevitable, but let us be extremely careful in its implementation.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, privatisation of hawker centres like the privatisation of Government hospitals will only mean one thing, ie, costs will go up. It is estimated that when the hawker centres are privatised, stall rentals will go up four or five times from its current levels and food

Column: 601

prices will cost between 20% and 25% more. At the more lucrative hawker centres, stall rentals will become quite substantial and food prices there will also be higher than the less lucrative spots.

    Hawker centres are traditional places where cheap food can be bought. The Government has declared that its policy is to maintain reasonably low prices of food at hawker centres so that workers need not pay too much on food and also to keep the cost of living down. In the past, when hawkers raised their food prices unreasonably, they were quickly warned by the Ministry not to do so. As a result, food prices at Government hawker centres have been kept fairly low and stable all these years. Due to low food prices at hawker centres, nearly all workers eat at hawker centres. Families also regularly eat out at hawker centres. Often they do so out of convenience. Both spouses in the family have to work long hours and they just do not have the time to cook and neither can they afford to employ a maid to do the cooking for them as the salaries are now quite prohibitive. Many Singaporeans therefore are quite dependent on hawker centres for their food.

    When privatisation comes, food prices will increase. Workers will have to pay more and they naturally will want more pay. Privatisation of hawker centres will thus be inflationary to our economy. I think it is not right for the Government to change its policy. Instead of preserving the low price of food at hawker centres, it wants to make money out of them. Workers are quite dependent on hawker centres. The present system seems to be doing well and should be preserved.

    Government runs substantial budget surpluses every year. Why the need for additional income? In any event, the Government will soon be introducing the consumption tax and it can get additional revenue from that source and need not earn additional money from hawker centres. Is the Ministry of the Environment finding it burdensome to run hawker centres? If it does, then it should follow

Column: 602

the example of the HDB. The HDB has divested all the common property in housing estates to Town Councils for them to maintain. Likewise, the Environment Ministry can hand over the management of hawker centres situated in each town to the relevant Town Councils. This is one way out, rather than turning hawker centres into commercial ventures to reap hefty profits out of them.

     Encik Ibrahim Othman (Bedok GRC): Sir, the Malaysia-Singapore Joint Committee on the Environment was formed in December last year. It seeks to serve as a forum for the exchange of experience and information on pollution control and also discusses environmental matters of mutual interest.

    During the first meeting, many issues were discussed. Among others, issues discussed were motor vehicle emission, air quality monitoring, water quality in the Straits of Johor, unleaded petrol, diesel fuel quality, industrial emission and hazardous chemical management. I wish to ask the Minister the progress of this Joint Committee.

    As we are actively promoting the growth triangle between Johor, Singapore and Batam, I wish to ask whether the Ministry of the Environment has any intention to involve Batam in this Joint Committee. I think we should seriously consider this matter as whatever they do in Johor and Batam, we will also be affected.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Chairman, Sir, I fully agree with the views expressed by Dr Koh Lam Son on the subject of privatisation of food centres. In any policy or proposal affecting stallholders in food centres, careful consideration will be given to minimise their displacement - and where possible, every opportunity will be given for them to continue their trade.

    Sir, at this point of time, my Ministry has not finalised the policy on privatisation, as the matter requires very, very careful consideration before a firm decision is taken. In the meantime, my Ministry is looking into the feasibility of renovating selected hawker centres, as Dr Koh Lam Son has suggested earlier on. The renovated centres will have bigger

Column: 603

stalls, bigger circulation and refreshment areas. They will also have modern facilities such as automatic washing machines and also central fume exhaust systems.

    Mr Chiam See Tong has said that when hawker centres are privatised, the cost of food sold at these centres may go up as high as 20-25%. And as workers usually depend on these hawker centres, the increase in food prices will certainly affect these workers.

    Sir, I do not think I could agree with what Mr Chiam has said, because food prices charged by existing private food centres which pay higher rentals and have high overheads, according to our investigations, are only marginally higher than those by hawker centres run by the Ministry of the Environment or by statutory boards. In any case, as I mentioned earlier, my Ministry has not finalised its decision on the privatisation of hawker centres.

    I now turn to the Malaysia-Singapore Joint Committee on the Environment which was raised by Encik Ibrahim Othman. The first meeting of the Malaysia-Singapore Joint Committee on the Environment was held on 5th February this year. At that meeting, environmental issues of current concerns to both Singapore and Malaysia were discussed and these included motor vehicular emissions, unleaded petrol and industrial emissions. The Joint Committee agreed on regular exchange of information and experience on environmental management and control. They have also agreed on stepping up and coordinating enforcement actions against black smoke emissions from vehicles.

    A Working Group comprising officers from both countries has been formed to look into the development of procedures to coordinate and to deal with environmental issues such as oil spills in the Straits of Johore, transboundary movement of hazardous chemicals and industrial pollution.

    Encik Ibrahim Othman wants to know the progress made by this Joint Committee. Of the list of topics discussed at the first meeting held in Johore on 5th February, the one that has been implemented

Column: 604

is the topic on Motor Vehicle Emission. Currently, both Singapore and Malaysia adopt the same testing methods and equipment as well as enforcement standard for smoke emission from diesel vehicles. Both countries have agreed to coordinate and step up enforcement against smoky diesel vehicles. The results of the stricter enforcement action will be monitored for three months and information on repeat offenders will be exchanged between the two countries for follow up action.

    The Working Group which I mentioned just now is looking into the implementation of the other topics and will be making its recommendations to the Joint Committee when it next meets in July.

    The setting up of the Malaysia-Singapore Joint Committee on the Environment has been very timely, Sir. The two countries are physically very close to each other and share common problems along the Straits of Johore. Batam Island, on the other hand, is physically further away. And at this point of time, only light industries are allowed to be set up there. By and large, these light industries are clean and therefore their impact on the environment here in Singapore would not be significant.

    It is also gratifying to note that the Indonesian authorities are also keen to control and minimise pollution from these industries to safeguard the tourism potential of Batam Island.

    The subject of the Joint Committee on the Environment between Batam and Singapore has not been raised by my counterpart in Jakarta. Should he raise it, I am more than willing to consider.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Chairman, can I have a clarification from the Minister? He says that as far as his Ministry's investigation goes, there is only a marginal difference in prices between the food at private hawker centres and at the Government ones. Could the Minister tell me which private hawker centres he is referring to? I have personal knowledge of this matter. There is one private hawker centre at High Street Centre and there is a neighbouring Government hawker centre at Empress Place Transit Hawker

Column: 605

Centre. The price differential there is about 20-25%. A bowl of mee at the Government hawker centre costs only $1.50. The minimum price at the private hawker centre is $2. As for coffee, without milk it is 40 cents at the Government hawker centre and 50 cents at the private hawker centre. With milk, it is 50 cents at the Government hawker centre and 60 cents at the private hawker centre.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Chairman, Sir, I think it is most unfortunate for Mr Chiam to patronise that particular hawker centre. What I am talking about are the general private hawker centres in Singapore. We have done our survey and found that many of them are charging only marginally higher than those run by the statutory boards or by the Environment Ministry.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: Sir, I thank the Minister for all the replies and I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
1.00 pm

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (Boon Lay): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head M be reduced by $10 in respect of Code MC 1500 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, through public education and imposition of fines, Singapore has earned for itself the reputation of being a clean and fine city. The state of cleanliness in the public places gives tourists the impression that all Singaporeans are very well behaved. But if you go around the housing estates, you will discover, to your horror, how filthy the estate can be, especially during certain times of the day. It is litter, litter, everywhere. But in spite of all the campaigns and public education, the number of littering offences is still significant. The Ministry of the Environment has to employ a large contingent of enforcement officers to take enforcement actions against littering and spitting offenders. In the past the HDB officers are empowered to take enforcement action. But some town councils are reluctant to take on such enforcement role. So I would like to ask the Minister what plan does

Column: 606

the Ministry have to resolve the manpower problem. Would the Ministry contemplate appointing volunteers, for instance, who would report offenders to the Ministry? And what other alternatives would the Ministry consider?

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Sir, a civilised society takes good care of its environment. Our Singapore society is edging towards that type of a civilised society. But in the meantime, we do face real but manageable problems in littering, spitting in public places and improper use of public toilets.

    While Singaporeans are proud of our city, I have noticed, like my GPC Chairman, that littering is still a problem in our housing estates. The housing estates are spick and span once our hardworking cleaners have done their job. But come late afternoon, litters begin to pile up. This problem gets worse when inconsiderate people spit in public places.

    Previously, HDB officers used to police our housing estates. Now town councils are called upon to do the job, but they do not have sufficient manpower to do the policing. So what can be done? There is a suggestion, as my GPC Chairman has stated, to get the volunteer enforcing officers to issue tickets to the litterbugs and the spitters. But is this desirable? If so, how do we go about getting and training the volunteers?

    I remember that some two years ago the Minister for the Environment made a call in this House to ask the public to give a helping hand by reporting spitting cases. May I humbly ask him how was the response thus far?

    I would like to second guess that unless there is a major disaster like, say, the East Coast beach is seriously polluted, it may be difficult to get volunteers to help. Most Singaporeans are reticent by nature. They would prefer others to do the summoning. But do we need people to enforce the law? How then do we do that? Somehow, manpower must be increased to ensure that the litterbugs and the spitters do not continue to dirty our clean city. We are one and only one city-state. We need to

Column: 607

take good care of it. No one else would do it for us. We have to do it all ourselves. So unless litterbugs clean up the act, we must make sure that they do not dirty our environment.

    I would like to ask the Minister whether he would consider increasing its own manpower to keep our city clean and green. And, if not, maybe the increment of manpower can come about by way of using other uniformed groups, such as other environment officers who are not presently involved, and what about the Traffic Police, Volunteer Special Constabulary, or even the national servicemen?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Chairman, Sir, my Ministry's plans are really to focus on public education and enforcement. We will reach out to the students through the schools and to the general community through grassroots organisations. But in the long term, Sir, my Ministry hopes that citizens will refrain from littering because of a greater sense of social responsibility and environmental consciousness. However, Sir, enforcement against those who litter will still continue. In this respect, my Ministry welcomes any help it can get.

    Sir, for the information of this House, to-date five Town Councils, namely, Jurong East, Potong Pasir, Tiong Bahru, Brickworks and Toa Payoh, have volunteered to help by getting their Town Council members, their staff and management agents to be empowered under the Environmental Public Health Act to take enforcement actions against littering and other offences. I am also pleased to report that members of the public are now giving feedback to my Ministry whenever they come across motorists who litter. Many of these members of the public have indicated that they will testify in court when called upon to do so. I applaud their civic consciousness and hope that there will be more like them. Therefore, at this point of time, I do not see the need for my Ministry to form organised volunteer groups, as suggested by Mr Goh Chee Wee, to enforce against littering.

    With regard to the recommendation by Dr Koh Lam Son that perhaps my Ministry could consider using other uniformed

Column: 608

groups to help us carry out the enforcement action, we will certainly look into the recommendation. But I would appeal to Town Councils to follow the examples of the five I have mentioned just now and get themselves empowered under the Environmental Public Health Act.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: Sir, let me speak on the next subject on food hygiene.

    During the previous budget debate, I raised the question of illegal food factory which posed a health hazard to the consumers. I believe the Ministry has stepped up action to stamp out the illegal food factories. I would like to ask the Minister whether the Ministry has succeeded in wiping out completely all the illegal food factories in Singapore.

     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): Sir, what I am going to say now is not because these last few days Members of Parliament have been lunching on hawker food but because in Singapore eating out has become a way of life for most people. This could be because most of us are too busy to cook and have to rely on hawker or restaurant food for our meals. Therefore, it is important that the food sold at hawker centres and restaurants must be hygienically prepared or manufactured by licensed sources and safe for human consumption. The environment around the hawker centres and restaurant kitchens must also be clean and dry. Food handlers must handle food hygienically at all times and be neatly clad.

    Unfortunately, this is still not the case in some eating centres today. One can still find instances of unhygienic food preparation and food handling as well as dirty hawker stalls and restaurant kitchens. It may be possible that these offenders are not deterred by the small amount of fines imposed by the courts relative to the severity of their offences. Would the Minister kindly inform the House what is the quantum of the fines generally imposed by the courts for food offences, and whether such fines are adequate to have the desired deterrent effect? How many offenders have been sentenced to the maximum penalty by way of fine or

Column: 609

imprisonment or both? Has the number of illegal food manufacturers, suppliers and vendors prosecuted increased or decreased? Further, could he provide a breakdown of the fines in 1990 so as to confirm or deny the point that the amount of fines for food offences was generally on the low side and have no deterrent value?
